text:
Time Series Methods:
Pediatric Mental Health in the COVID-Era ED


    Will Simmons
Weill Cornell Division of Biostatistics
8 April 2025

Presented to:
Weill Cornell Department of Emergency Medicine

What is timeseries data?


Data measured at regular intervals over time

Can vary by frequency (e.g., every year, every minute)
  


Examples: ED visit counts, patient vitals, rainfall totals

Research context


Rising mental health-related ED visits among children and teens

We suspected seasonal patterns and COVID-related changes to visit volumes

section: Why do timeseries methods matter here?
text:
Why do timeseries methods matter here?


Quantifies trends, seasonality, and anomalies





In today’s motivating example, these methods helped answer:

Are there seasonal patterns to mental health ED visits?
Have mental health ED visits increased? If so, how much?
Did COVID disrupt visit patterns?

Motivating example




Kids are brought to the ED for a number of reasons

Mental health (MH) increasingly one of those reasons

MH-related pediatric ED visits seasonal and increasing

Our data1



Weekly pediatric ED visits for mental health concerns.

NYC-area hospitals, 2016–2022.

Covers pre-pandemic, peak COVID, and post-peak periods.





Goal: Understand how visit patterns changed during COVID and what that could mean for future care.

Data source: INSIGHT Clinical Research Network. https://insightcrn.org/our-data/.

Visualization = key!













This figure “smoothes” noise in our timeseries data using a rolling average. 
Descriptive visualizations can lead us to research questions!

What did we notice?



Seasonality: peaks April/November, troughs January/July 
Trend fairly flat over time 
Changes post-COVID (blue line)?

What we wanted to know
   

Research question:
What would visit rates have looked like without COVID?

What we wanted to know


Specifically:



Was the increase we noticed real or random?

How much did COVID disrupt seasonal patterns?

What could this mean for mental health ED care going forward?




Timeseries models helped us answer these questions.

How we used timeseries methods

Compared expected visits with reality, by COVID wave

Key findings



COVID increased MH-related visits, overall and for specific groups/diagnoses.
Timeseries models quantified these changes.



Specific groups: higher than expected among - Female patients - Adolescents (12-17 years) - Asian patients
Specific diagnoses: - Anxiety and depressive disorders - Suicidality/self-harm - Substance use disorders - Eating disorders

Closing thoughts


Timeseries models can turn raw ED data into actionable insights
Do you have a question that could be answered using timeseries methods?
Timeseries models generally require:

A well-defined research question + hypothesis (I can help)
Sufficient data (depends, but good start is 50+ timepoints over multiple years)
